abstract: A new Web site mines the “deep Web” to find information on people not revealed by standard search engines.
snippet: A new Web site mines the “deep Web” to find information on people not revealed by standard search engines.
lead_paragraph: We’ve all heard the warnings about how difficult it is to erase our electronic tracks. A new Web site, Pipl.com, can give you a vivid sense — in just a few seconds — of what people would find about you if they searched a little deeper than Google allows.

headline.main: When Googling a Person (or Yourself) Isn’t Enough

abstract: In his latest attack on Yahoo’s board, Carl Icahn takes aim at Yahoo’s inability to compete with Google.
snippet: In his latest attack on Yahoo’s board, Carl Icahn takes aim at Yahoo’s inability to compete with Google.
lead_paragraph: UPDATE 1:45 P.M.: Yahoo files definitive proxy statement.

headline.main: From Carl Icahn, With Little Love

abstract: Apple is showing new ways for the iPhone to check news, sports and e-mail. But it appears to be willing to ask users to pay fees to do so rather than subsidizing content and services with advertising.
snippet: Apple is showing new ways for the iPhone to check news, sports and e-mail. But it appears to be willing to ask users to pay fees to do so rather than subsidizing content and services with advertising.
lead_paragraph: Steve Jobs  showed the iPhone giving news updates, checking baseball scores and reading medical information. He introduced a new online service, Me.com, with e-mail, photo storage, calendars and more.

headline.main: Take That, Google: No Ads From Apple
